journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Adaptive predictive control of input-delay motor systems enhanced with supervisory strategies

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, Asia University, Taiwan, Republic of China
2Department of Electronic Engineering, Jinwen University of Science and Technology, Taiwan, Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Jiing-Dong Hwang, Department of Electronic Engineering, Jinwen University of Science and Technology, 99 An Chung Road, Taipei County, Hsintien 23154, Taiwan, Republic of China. Email: ditherman@just.edu.tw

abstract.p: The adaptive predictive controller design for the problem of input delay based on the Lyapunov approach is discussed in the present paper. The main problem of designing a predictive controller is to determine the values of control gains and to compensate for the effect of input delay for the predictable state. We first propose a novel predictive controller called the adaptive predictive controller and use it in place of the traditional adaptive controller used in the nonlinear control system without any input delay. Second, we adopt a simplex algorithm that can search the optimal timing for a prediction to compensate for the effect of input delay. In the meantime, we use the techniques of neural network predictive model and direct adaptive scheme to design the adaptive predictive controller for some class of nonlinear systems with input delay. To enhance the input-delay systems, stability to the size of input delay, a supervised control scheme and an adaptive predictive controller of unknown nonlinear systems with input delay are proposed. The supervised adaptive control law aims to pull the states back to the pre-specified state region and reduce the overshoot towards an extra stabilizing input. Finally, some computer simulation results are provided to illustrate the proposed methods.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During recent years, a number of research activities have been concerned with the topic of tracking design of nonlinear systems with input delay1–4 due to the slow energy transmission in plants and the input delay naturally existing in practical systems. The existence of time delay is frequently a cause of instability due to encounters with various closed-loop engineering systems.5–9

The model-based adaptive controllers have recently been widely used in many practical control problems owing to their powerful nonlinear modeling capabilities and adaptabilities. However, typical indirect adaptive control10,11 has structural complexities. Inspired by direct adaptive control cases,12–15 we extend a predictive controller and supervisory control to the practical system with input delay and modeling error. In these cases of real applications represented by g(X)>0 together with the affine constraint, the approach is due to the nonlinear control theory of Isidori,16 but all of them neglect the generalized modeling error in the nonlinear system. Existence of the generalized modeling error and input delay may be a potential source of instability for control designs based on the assumption that the model exactly matches the plant.17 Thus, a robust design of adaptive predictive controller for nonlinear systems with input delay needs further study.

In this paper, a neural network model18 is used to design a predictive controller. Over the past few years, neural network-based modeling had become an active research field because of its unique merits in solving complex nonlinear system identification and control problems.19 Hence, we use the techniques of predictive modeling based on the neural network modeling method and direct adaptive scheme based on the Lyapunov approach to design the adaptive predictive controller for some class of nonlinear systems with input delay. Unlike conventional modeling, neural network modeling is essentially a multi-model approach in which individual neurons are combined to describe the global behavior of the system.

More recently, the model-based predictive control (MPC) design20–22 has been widely used in nonlinear systems without any input delay. However, in practical control systems, the plants are always nonlinear and include input delay, and the MPC schemes for nonlinear systems without input delay are so complicated that they are not suitable for practical application with input delay. Therefore, we need to develop a simple adaptive predictive control scheme that can avoid the unstable response of nonlinear systems because of the effect of input delay.

The purpose of the present paper is to derive a tracking stability criterion for a model-based adaptive predictive controller to guarantee the stability of nonlinear systems with input delay. Therefore, the neural network model is employed to approximate the nonlinear system with input delay. The adaptive predictive control design is carried out based on two Lyapunov functions and the projection method.

sec.title: System description and problem formulation
sec.p: The input-delay nonlinear system dynamics is represented in a single-input/single-output (SISO) state-space representation as

where u(Xd) is the control input with time delay, and Xd≡[x(t−τd),x·(t−τd),…,x(n−1)(t−τd)]T=[x1(t−τd),x2(t−τd),…,xn(t−τd)]T=[xd1,xd2,…,xdn]T∈ℜn×1, τd>0 is the input delay; emod(t) is the modeling error, |emod(t)|≤eU; x(t) is the output of the system without any input delay, which cannot be measured in the practical system; X=Xd(τd=0). In this paper, the state x(t)=x1(t) will be estimated as x^(t) by using a neural network model,18 and if we assume that τd is estimated well by using the simplex method,23 then

sec.title: Controller design
sec.p: First, we define the reference input as yr=xr1(t), tracking error as e=yr−x(t)≈yr−x^(t)=e^. Yr is a reference input vector, so we have Yr=[yr,y·r,…,yr(n−1)]T=[xr1(t),xr2(t),…,xrn(t)]T. E is a tracking error vector, so we have E=[e,e·,…,e(n−1)]T≈[e^,e^.,…,e^(n−1)]T=E^.

sec.title: Predictive model design
sec.p: The series–parallel identification model (SPM) is used here for the prediction x^(t) of the system output x(t).18 In this SPM, the output of the plant is fed back into the identification model as shown in Figure 1(b). Based on a genetic algorithm (GA) and the steepest descent method (SDM), a hybrid algorithm for the learning of neural networks to identify complex nonlinear systems by adjusting weights and bias between neurons has been proposed.18 In the present paper, neural networks trained by combining GA and SDM are used in the prediction of nonlinear systems with input delays that achieve a superior performance in the identification of this kind of system.

Observe that the method of steepest descent is simple, easy to apply, and each iteration is fast. A traditional method, SDM has been used over a long period of time in training the weight and biasing of neural networks. This way achieves rapid convergence in learning, but the deficiency about a local optimum in this method is clear. Lately, in the field of training neural networks, the GA has been used widely to take the place of SDM owing to the better function of the former. GAs can reach the global optimum; nevertheless, the process of reproduction takes much longer. Thus the convergence rate becomes much slower than by SDM. It would enhance the learning performance if one could complement the other. Therefore, integrating SDM and GA into a hybrid algorithm would be beneficial to the training of a neural network.

In the neural network used in the present work (Figure 1(c)), a hyperbolic tangential function is chosen as the activation function of the hidden layer and a linear function is chosen as the activation function of the output layer. For convenience, a series of training results for the neural network predictive model with input delay, τd=0.01,0.02,…,0.5, is obtained by the hybrid algorithm18 in advance.

sec.title: Estimation of input delay
sec.p: Taking tracking performance together with the estimation of input delay τd into consideration, the overall performance index, J, is defined as
where tf is the termination time of simulation.

list-item.p: Remark 1. A major field of application for the Nelder–Mead simplex algorithm23 deals with nonlinear optimization problems without derivative information. For this kind of problem, the simplex method allows one to find a solution close to the global optimum within fewer steps in comparison to the more powerful DIRECT (DIviding RECTangle) algorithm or evolutionary computation techniques when proper initial values are given.

sec.p: The input delay τd is then estimated such that the overall performance index J is minimized. From Remark 1, we propose the Nelder–Mead simplex method for guiding the minimization procedure in the present paper. The method, simplex initialization, is a local optimization algorithm which is sensitive to the initial guess; however, multiple trials with random initial values can alleviate this problem. Details are presented in the subsequent example.

In this paper, tape delays are the fixed parameters of dynamical neural network and they have no relationship with time delays. The parameters of the selected artificial neural network structure with tape delays are trained by SDM with shuffled data and simplex initialization to avoid getting into a local minimum, which is also one of our further research topics. Besides, the present study work is related to the extant literature;15 basically, the present study is an extension of the extant literature.15

sec.title: Neural network predictive model of the DC motor system
sec.p: The neural network with tape delays as trained by SDM with shuffled data and simplex initialization to avoid getting into a local minimum, which consists of a three-layer structure (Figure 1(c)), is chosen for the present study. The architecture of the predictive model is in the form of 4-12-3, where the input layer has four channels p=[X(t−τd)T,u]T∈ℜ4×1, τd=0.5s; the hidden-layer function F0(·)∈ℜ12×1 has 12 neurons; and the output-layer function F1(·)∈ℜ3×1 has three neurons for X^. The parameters of the neural network predictive model are as follows
where

sec.title: Adaptive predictive controller of the DC motor system
sec.p: In the following, in order to compare the performance of various adaptive control algorithms, simulation results are presented for three different cases:

list-item.p: the control scheme that lacks a predictive model in the control law (Case 1);14
the adaptive predictive control algorithm proposed in this study, with the predictions of X under the known input delays τd=0.01and0.1s, respectively (Case 2);
the adaptive predictive control method proposed in this study, with the optimal prediction of X under the unknown input delay τd=0.5s (Case 3).

sec.p: Hence, the major difference between Case 2 and Case 3 is as follows: Case 2 does not need to use the simplex method to estimate the input delays as the input delays are assumed to be known, but Case 3 does need to use the simplex method to estimate the bigger input delay because the input delay is assumed to be unknown.

In Case 2 and Case 3, we use the proposed transfer function (see Figure 3) to design the direct adaptive controller. The simulation results of the predictions of X under the known input delays τd=0.01,0.1and0.5s are shown in Figure 4(a) to (c) based on the closed-loop predictive model (see Figure 5). The major difference between Figure 1(c) and Figure 5 is as follows. Figure 1(c) shows the open-loop predictive model structure; that is, u is a random control input for training this model. Hence, the training data are prearranged for off-line and batch training purposes. However, Figure 5 shows the closed-loop predictive model structure; that is, u is an on-line control force for the physical system. Table 1 summarizes the simulation results of Figure 4(a) to (c).

sec.p: In Case 1 (see Figure 6), we see the importance of the neural network predictive model in the control laws of Case 2 and Case 3 (see Figures 7 and 8). From Figures 9 and 10, for Case 2 and Case 3, we observe that the proposed supervised adaptive predictive control law aims to pull the state or output of the system back to the pre-specified trajectory of the reference input. Table 2 summarizes the simulation results of Figure 7(a) and (b); Table 3 summarizes the simulation results of Figure 9(a) and (b). Finally, Figures 11 and 12 show, respectively, the values of performance index J for the searching history of input delay τd=0.5s by using the simplex method and the adaptation processes of the adaptation parameters a,b,ϕ1 in Case 3.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The main purpose of the present work was to study the supervised adaptive predictive control strategy in the tracking problem of a DC motor system to reduce the input-delay effects on tracking accuracy. The nonlinear input-delay relationship between the DC motor and its control system renders the tracking problem difficult to model and analyze. In this paper, we introduced the closed-loop and open-loop neural network predictive models, and investigated the delay existing in the feedback state and the delay-independent stability for this system. Then, a design methodology for stabilization and robustness of this kind of input-delay nonlinear system was presented. Moreover, the stability analysis and control design problems could be solved very efficiently in practice by projection techniques and adaptation laws. Consequently, simulation results showed that the supervised adaptive predictive control approach is both effective and relatively easy to apply.
